definition: to work hard while accomplishing little/to toil to no avail
to toil/labor/laborer/to put sb to trouble (of doing sth)/meritorious deed/to console (Taiwan pr. [lao4] for this sense)
and/as well as/and so/but (not)/yet (not)/(indicates causal relation)/(indicates change of state)/(indicates contrast)
not to have/no/none/not/to lack/un-/-less
meritorious deed or service/achievement/result/service/accomplishment/work (physics)

sentences.english: I tried to change it but failed.
sentences.chinese: 我努力改变这种状况，但劳而无功。

sentences.english: However, Grunger's immense armada caused the campaign to end in failure.
sentences.chinese: 但格鲁吉尔的庞大舰队使得塔科发动的战役劳而无功。

sentences.english: They tried to rally the pound sterling but in vain.
sentences.chinese: 他们企图恢复英镑币值，但劳而无功。

sentences.english: She tried to prevent the work from being done in vain .
sentences.chinese: 她试图防止工作做得劳而无功。

sentences.english: Gates had some reason to think Jobs' mission was worthless.
sentences.chinese: 盖茨是有理由认为乔布斯会劳而无功的。

sentences.english: Billions of dollars have been spent on long-range weather forecasting, but it is a fool's errand.
sentences.chinese: 数十亿美元花在远程气象预报上是一个劳而无功的事。

definition: futile endeavor (idiom)
to work to no avail (idiom)
twice the effort for half the result
to fail within sight of success (idiom); last-minute failure/to fall at the last hurdle/snatching defeat from the jaws of victory
to have accomplished nothing (idiom)
to fail to grasp the main points
using a wicker basket to draw water (idiom); wasted effort
to sit and waste a good opportunity (idiom); to lose the chance
lit. to want sth in haste, but cannot get there (idiom, from Analects); more haste, less speed/also written 欲速則不達|欲速则不达
to neglect the root and pursue the tip (idiom)/to neglect fundamentals and concentrate on details
waste of manpower and resources
achieving nothing
no room to advance or to retreat (idiom); at a loss/in a hopeless situation
lit. climb a tree to catch a fish (idiom); fig. to attempt the impossible
to struggle to cope (with a situation)/to be at one's wits' end
the gains do not make up for the losses (idiom)
